item.title: victor blanco, stargazer, dies at 92
item.description: mr. blanco, an astronomer, helped build a major outpost for american science in chile and shepherded it through revolution and economic turmoil.

item.title: google's rapidly rising expenses crimp earnings
item.description: google's first-quarter earnings came in below analyst projections as the internet search leader sped up hiring and increased spending other area ...

item.title: singapore faces life without lee
item.description: for most singaporeans, a government without lee kuan yew at the helm or very near it seemed inconceivable. that break will now come sooner than expected.

item.title: the five musts every parent, child and family needs to be successful and happy
item.description: i find it ironic that the role of  “parent” comes with so much inherent power – and yet we, as parents, often feel ...

item.title: fifa confirms two-horse race for president
item.description: mohamed bin hammam will be the only challenger for the fifa presidency when incumbent sepp blatter stands for re-election on june 1, soccer's world governing body confirmed on monday.

item.title: european union salaries a haven for eastern europeans
item.description: the huge difference between the latvian prime minister?s salary and the pay of latvians working in brussels shows how hopes of rising wages were dashed in the bloc?s east.

item.title: europe: belarus: ex-presidential candidates are sentenced
item.description: belarus sentenced two former presidential candidates to lengthy prison terms for organizing a large protest against elections held in december.

item.title: the pride of connersville is the soul of butler
item.description: an indiana town is hanging on to matt howard's exploits as butler makes a second consecutive run toward the final four.

item.title: film business booms at cannes amid flurry of deals
item.description: the business of cinema is roaring back to life at cannes after a prolonged bout of gloom, finding renewed strength in money from china, the return of hollywood studios and the pulling power of a-list stars.

item.title: names at september 11 memorial grouped as family, work buddies
item.description: names of all 2,982 people who died in the september 11 attacks will be grouped as friends, work buddies and families on bronze panels at a national memorial opening in new york, organizers announced.

item.title: n.b.a. roundup: bulls clinch top seed in the east
item.description: chicago, which has won six straight and 18 of 20, defeated cleveland to secure home-court advantage through the first three rounds of the playoffs.

item.title: afghan policeman kills nato soldiers, protests continue
item.description: -sharif, afghanistan - a "rogue" afghan border policeman shot dead two foreign soldiers on a training mission in northern province faryab on monday, and hundreds took to the streets for a fourth day of protests against the burning of a koran by a fundamentalist u.s. pastor.

item.title: worst attack on u.n. in afghanistan kills at least 7
item.description: -sharif, afghanistan - afghans protesting the burning of a koran by an obscure u.s. pastor over-ran a u.n. compound on friday and killed at least seven international staff in the deadliest-ever attack on the united nations in afghanistan.

item.title: qantas to curb flights, cut jobs to offset fuel
item.description: australia's qantas airways plans to scale back some flights and cut management jobs to help offset soaring fuel prices and an estimated a$140 million ($144 million) hit to its earnings from a string of natural disasters in key markets.

item.title: ensign aide indicted on seven counts
item.description: doug hampton, the former senior aide to senator john ensign, republican of nevada, was indicted on thursday for violating a one-year lobbying ban.

item.title: no repeat of chernobyl disaster for japan: experts
item.description: japan should not expect a repeat of the chernobyl nuclear disaster after an explosion blew the roof off one of its nuclear power plants that had been shaken in a huge earthquake, experts said on saturday.

item.title: venezuela's chavez wins journalism school prize
item.description: venezuelan president hugo chavez, who critics accuse of stifling press freedom, was given a prize by an argentine journalism school on tuesday for his contribution to "popular communication."

item.title: "the voice" tv coaches aim to boost singers' talent
item.description: the stars of upcoming tv singing contest "the voice" on tuesday sought to contrast their new show with top-rated "american idol" by saying they will be boosters for the contestants compared to critical judges.

item.description: the bowl championship series announced monday it has stripped southern california of its national championship in 2004 due to the ineligibility ...

item.title: some gas stations are starting to charge $5 a gallon
item.description: as gas prices continue to rise, we're starting to find isolated instances of stations charging $5 for gallon a regular case.

item.title: pictures, letters of king assassin shown in online museum
item.description: a memphis county official has opened an online museum of case files, personal correspondence and little-seen black-and-white images chronicling the jail time of james earl ray, who killed civil rights leader martin luther king jr. 43 years ago this monday.

item.description: wednesday's game 5 comeback might have been no more than a last stand for the aging spurs, but they have defined continuity and comity for years.

item.description: israel asked the united nations to help prevent activists from sailing to gaza on the anniversary of the israeli raid on a turkish ship that tried to breach the blockade of the territory last may.

item.title: japan's central bank keeps key rate at near zero
item.description: japan's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at virtually zero friday to shore up a quake-battered economy.

item.title: dupont extends danisco offer after low uptake
item.description: u.s. chemicals group dupont extended its $6 billion takeover bid for danisco by four weeks after holders of only 6 percent of the danish company's shares had accepted the offer.

item.title: qantas to cut capacity, reduce management to offset fuel
item.description: australia's qantas airways plans to axe capacity and management jobs and retire some aircraft early under cost-cutting measures aimed at offsetting soaring fuel prices and the impact of natural disasters in japan, new zealand and australia.

item.title: off with its head: 'wonderland' musical to close on sunday
item.description: the costly production based on lewis carroll's novels will close on sunday, not quite one month after it opened at the marquis theater.

item.description: president obama's release of his birth certificate last week aimed to quell any doubts he was born in the usa.

item.title: china premium car market prize worth the hurdles
item.description: luxury car makers that have learned the ropes in the familiar markets of europe and the united states are having to adapt to new ways in china, but with the market expected to boom, they have little choice but to get on board.

item.title: climate change bringing infection, hunger, illness
item.description: climate change threatens far more than our environment. it's already led to the spread of infectious diseases and respiratory ailments across the globe and contributed to thousands of deaths through heat waves and other extreme weather events. it's even fueled recent revolts in the middle east and north africa.

item.title: greece has ways to fix debt woes, but all lead to misery
item.description: the european union has a number of options to restructure greece's debt; the trick is to allow the euro to survive and to stem any further collapse of greece or other at-risk countries.

item.title: reuters concerned for photographer held in syria
item.description: reuters said on saturday it was concerned for the safety of its photographer khaled al-hariri, who has been detained by syrian authorities for five days.

item.title: al qaeda leader, 17 others killed in iraq jail clash
item.description: eighteen people, including an al qaeda leader and a senior iraqi counter-terrorism official, died in a battle between inmates and security officers during a jailbreak attempt in baghdad sunday, security officials said.

item.title: yemen forces clash in sanaa, violence kills 5
item.description: rival yemeni forces clashed in the capital sanaa on wednesday, killing two people, as the opposition awaited clarification from gulf arab mediators on the timeframe for a proposed transfer of the president's powers.

item.title: carter says four tumors were found on his brain
item.description: the hall of fame gary carter has four small tumors on his brain. he will be examined further on thursday.

item.title: fire in chicago suburb kills three adults, three children
item.description: an early morning fire roared through a suburban chicago apartment building on sunday, killing six people, three of them children, and injuring 12 other people, authorities said.

item.description: one in 16 preschoolers has visual impairment in at least one eye, suggests a new study of australian kids.

item.description: diamond foods will merge with pringles, a unit of procter & gamble, in a deal valued at $2.35 billion.

item.description: males have two-thirds of speaking roles, while females are more likely to appear nude.

item.description: holder phil mickelson again zig-zagged his way across augusta national and was relieved to conclude an up-and-down second round on friday in position to mount a masters charge over the weekend.

item.title: sony could benefit from shortages of canon, nikon slrs
item.description: sony says the factory that makes its popular alpha a55 slr hasn't experienced production issues.

item.title: truck crashes into vehicles in tel aviv, 1 dead
item.description: a truck driver drove into cars and pedestrians in tel aviv on sunday, an annual palestinian protest day, killing a man and injuring 17 people, and police said they were investigating whether it was a political attack.

item.title: gunmen dump beheaded bodies outside school in mexico
item.description: suspected drug hitmen dumped six headless bodies outside a school in northern mexico monday a day after forensics pulled victims out of a nearby mass grave in a stream of unrelenting violence that is pressuring mexican president felipe calderon.

item.title: damaging the earth to feed its people
item.description: humans are cultivating almost 40 percent of the land surface of the earth, and nearly a third of all the greenhouse gas emissions that are warming the planet comes from agriculture.

item.title: "tornado alley" spawns subculture of storm chasers
item.description: when the sky grew dark, power lines snapped and trees fell in alabama on wednesday, jeff shardell pointed his modified yukon vehicle directly toward the deadly tornadoes.

item.title: a wide-open chase for the hart trophy
item.description: though it was not the case earlier in the season, there are no clear-cut favorites for the hart trophy, which is given to the player judged most valuable to his team.

item.title: warhol's elizabeth taylor portrait to be auctioned

item.description: for many migrants, particularly from sub-saharan africa, life in libya, despite exploitation and abuse, offered economic opportunity.

item.title: nearly 50 percent chance of record fargo flood
item.description: the chance of record red river flooding at fargo, north dakota this spring has grown to nearly 50 percent and forecasts of how high the water will crest have increased all along the river, the national weather service said on friday.

item.description: a lawsuit filed by four young men who accused the megachurch pastor bishop eddie long of sexual misconduct has been resolved, lawyers for both sides said thursday.

item.title: delaware, enjoying unexpected cash, looks to tax cuts
item.description: delaware governor jack markell on thursday proposed a series of tax cuts for residents and businesses in his state which, unlike many states, finds itself with an unexpected pile of cash.

item.description: a man survived with injuries after driving his car over the south rim of the grand canyon by accident, authorities said on wednesday.

item.title: too young for kindergarten? tide turning against 4-year-olds
item.description: connecticut is considering holding back students born after oct. 1, a process known as redshirting, so they won't be overwhelmed by peers who have already turned 5.

item.description: texas governor rick perry on thursday appealed the federal government's denial of a major disaster declaration for wildfires in the lone star state.

item.title: home safety products can prevent injuries in kids
item.description: installing stair gates, cabinet locks, and smoke detectors led to a drop in injury rates in young children in a new study that provided and set up the safety products in almost 200 homes.

item.description: mobile telecom gear venture nokia siemens networks closed its $975 million acquisition of motorola solutions' mobile gear unit on friday, four months behind the original schedule

item.title: bill clinton home made a national historic site
item.description: former president bill clinton returned to his childhood home on saturday to celebrate its dedication as a national historical site.

item.description: the rich keep getting richer, both here in the united states and especially in the world's emerging markets.

item.description: doctors have long encouraged patients to slash their salt intake for good heart health.

item.description: wall street mostly fell, continuing to react to fed chief ben bernanke's wan assessment of the economy's near-term prospects.

item.description: a deal would allow general mills to continue distributing yoplait in the united states, as it has since 1977.
